title: Risk & Security
description: Explore your comfort with financial risk and what security means to you.

questions.text: When it comes to financial risk, I'm generally...
choices: Conservative—I prefer safe and steady
Moderate—calculated risks are okay
Comfortable—risk is part of growth
It depends on what's at stake

therapeutic.rationale: Risk tolerance is partly temperamental, partly learned. Conservative types prioritize safety; moderate types balance; comfortable types embrace uncertainty. Partners with different risk tolerances often clash on investments, career moves, and major decisions.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: The conservative partner may feel the risk-taker is reckless; the risk-taker may feel the conservative partner holds them back. Neither is wrong—you need to find your shared comfort zone.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared risk tolerance makes financial decisions easier. You naturally agree on how much uncertainty is acceptable.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What's shaped your relationship with financial risk? A good experience? A bad one? Your family?

choices: Having enough saved for any emergency
Knowing our basic needs are always covered
Freedom to make choices without money stress
Not having to worry about money day-to-day

therapeutic.rationale: Security means different things to different people. Emergency-focusers need a cushion; basics-focusers need stability; choice-focusers need freedom; worry-free focusers need peace. Knowing your partner's definition helps you build toward it.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different security definitions may mean different targets. The emergency-focuser may save more than the worry-free focuser thinks necessary. Understand each other's 'enough.'
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared security definition aligns your goals. You're working toward the same feeling of safety.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What would make you feel financially secure? Be specific. Is that achievable?

questions.text: When considering a financial opportunity with some risk, I want to...
choices: Research thoroughly before deciding
Trust my gut if it feels right
Talk it through with my partner first
Err on the side of caution

therapeutic.rationale: How you approach risky opportunities reveals your decision-making style. Researchers want data; gut-trusters want intuition; talkers want partnership; caution-errers want safety. These styles interact in couples.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different approaches may clash when opportunities arise. The gut-truster may feel the researcher is slow; the caution-errer may feel the gut-truster is impulsive. Honor both inputs.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared approach makes evaluating opportunities easier. You'll naturally move at the same pace.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: Think of a financial risk you took (or didn't). How did you decide? What would you do differently?

questions.text: If one of us wanted to take a big financial risk, I'd want us to...
choices: Discuss it fully and both be on board
Support each other even if we're unsure
Make sure it doesn't jeopardize our security
Have a backup plan before proceeding

therapeutic.rationale: How couples handle one person's risk-taking reveals trust and boundaries. Full-discussers need consensus; supporters prioritize partnership; security-guarders prioritize safety; planners need contingencies. All are valid.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different approaches may create tension when risks arise. The supporter may feel the discusser is unsupportive; the security-guarder may feel the supporter is careless. Find your shared approach before crisis.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared approach means you'll handle risk-taking the same way. This alignment helps during uncertain decisions.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How would you feel if your partner wanted to take a big financial risk? What would you need to feel okay?

questions.text: The role of financial safety nets (savings, insurance, etc.) in our life should be...
choices: A top priority—we build these first
Important but balanced with living life now
There when needed, not obsessed over
Discussed together based on our situation

therapeutic.rationale: Safety net philosophy reveals anxiety levels and values. Prioritizers need security first; balancers want both safety and enjoyment; light-touchers trust things will work out; discussers want alignment. These values shape major decisions.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: The prioritizer may feel the light-toucher is irresponsible; the light-toucher may feel the prioritizer is fear-driven. Both perspectives have wisdom—find your balance.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared philosophy makes planning easier. You agree on how important safety nets are.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How much in savings would make you sleep well at night? What's driving that number?
